paragraphs.text:
%md
#  __Portfolio scan results__
### Customer: *Acme*
### Date: *01/27/2020*
### Portfolio name: *Navigator Workshop sample applications*

#### Summary:
On `INSERT DATE` Pivotal's AppTx team conducted an Navigator workshop during which `Pivotal Application Analyzer` was used to scan a subset of Acme's application portfolio. 
This report summarizes the results of that scan. If you are reading this within an installation of `Zeppelin` and you would like to interact with the notebook you can find
help here: [https://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.8.2/](https://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.8.2/)

This report presents both summary and detail views of the application portfolio.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Portfolio Summary
A total of 9 applications were scanned, comprised of over half a million lines of source code. By industry standards, this is a small portfolio, but it is just a sample. Viewing the scores and other data gathered helps to understand how to use `PAA` in a broader context.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Files Type Distribution
The language profile of a portfolio shows the technology composition. Typically, `Java` or `.NET` account for most lines of code. `Java` accounts for just over *25* percent of the portfolio. We can also see which build systems are present, in this case `Maven`, a modern build system is present, however, `Ant`, a legacy build system is present as well. Also, *9.8* percent of the portfolio is `JavaScript`.

msg.data:

The language profile of a portfolio shows the technology composition. Typically, Java or .NET account for most lines of code. Java accounts for just over 25 percent of the portfolio. We can also see which build systems are present, in this case Maven, a modern build system is present, however, Ant, a legacy build system is present as well. Also, 9.8 percent of the portfolio is JavaScript.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### API Usage Distribution View
The API Profile indicate substantial legacy API usage that detracts from the portfolio's cloud readiness. `ejb` and `javaee` usage has a combined percentage of *28* percent. This could indicate stateful behaviors that impede migration into a cloud environment. Fully compliant `12-factor` applications avoid any type of file system usage since due to the ethereal nature of cloud environments. `Table 1`, below, provides a key to the impact of finding each technology.

`Table 1:`


|API | Possible Concern or Benefit|
| :------------- | :---------- |
|webprofile - webapp | indicates legacy web application|
|ejb - javaee | possible stateful enterprise java bean|
|jaxrs - jaxws | indicates RESTful web services already exist|
|third-party| not all third-party libraries are cloud ready|
|logging| all logging must be to the console, replacement or reconfiguration required|
|jpa - jdbc| indicates use of a database, ensure it is used as a backing service|
|jboss - jboss-import| jboss should be transistioned to a cloud friendly equivilent|
|soap | legacy messaging format. Can exist in cloud, but it should be replaced with RESTful services|
|json|Modern text-based format, indicates modern practices|
|stuts - jsf|Legacy user interface framework, should be replaced with modern framework|
|session| May indicate statefulness, should be investigated|
|jni| Java Native Interface, should be removed|
|io| Could indicate non-ephemeral storage, should be investigated|
|websphere|Legacy application server, should be remediated |
|jndi| Should be moved to modern equivilent|

msg.data:
API Usage Distribution View

The API Profile indicate substantial legacy API usage that detracts from the portfolio’s cloud readiness. ejb and javaee usage has a combined percentage of 28 percent. This could indicate stateful behaviors that impede migration into a cloud environment. Fully compliant 12-factor applications avoid any type of file system usage since due to the ethereal nature of cloud environments. Table 1, below, provides a key to the impact of finding each technology.

Table 1:

API Possible Concern or Benefit
webprofile - webapp indicates legacy web application
ejb - javaee possible stateful enterprise java bean
jaxrs - jaxws indicates RESTful web services already exist
third-party not all third-party libraries are cloud ready
logging all logging must be to the console, replacement or reconfiguration required
jpa - jdbc indicates use of a database, ensure it is used as a backing service
jboss - jboss-import jboss should be transistioned to a cloud friendly equivilent
soap legacy messaging format. Can exist in cloud, but it should be replaced with RESTful services
json Modern text-based format, indicates modern practices
stuts - jsf Legacy user interface framework, should be replaced with modern framework
session May indicate statefulness, should be investigated
jni Java Native Interface, should be removed
io Could indicate non-ephemeral storage, should be investigated
websphere Legacy application server, should be remediated
jndi Should be moved to modern equivilent

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Individual application scores
Scores may range from 1 to 10, however, scores below a 4 are rare. The higher scores indicate the application is more cloud-ready and will require less remediation. Scores higher than a 7, should be considered for `PAS`. Scores lower than 7 may require more remediation, thus the business value of the application my need to be considered. 

Score below 6.5 might be better candidates for PKS. The types of remediation are also critical. Some remediation types, such as Enterprise Java Beans, may require more extensive changes.

Typically, the patterns are seeking the usage of particular APIs, such as file I/O, where the repetition of the pattern indicates the degree to which the API is used and therefore the relative effort to remediate.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Detailed file based findings
Some patterns only appear as a single file in an application. The are typically configuration files. The scoring on these patterns is adjusted to account that only one instance will be found. The presence of the file indicates a possible use of legacy technology.

msg.data:
Detailed file based findings

Some patterns only appear as a single file in an application. The are typically configuration files. The scoring on these patterns is adjusted to account that only one instance will be found. The presence of the file indicates a possible use of legacy technology.

paragraphs.text: z.show(rddScoreDetailFileBased)
